Name: Robert E. Galer
Notes: For service in the Solomon Islands as the leader of a Marine fighter squadron

Name: William W. Galt †
Notes: For his leadership and courage in directing an assault against an entrenched force that had repulsed two previous attacks

Name: Archer T. Gammon †
Notes: While under fire from a German machine gun and tank , counterattacked the German force and forced them to retreat with grenade and small arms fire

Name: Joe Gandara †
Notes: Advanced voluntarily and alone toward an enemy position and destroyed three hostile machine guns before being fatally wounded

Name: Marcario Garcia
Notes: After realizing that his company could not advance because it was pinned down by enemy machine gun fire , on his own initiative , went alone and destroyed 2 enemy emplacements and captured 4 prisoners . Despite being wounded himself , he continued to fight on with his unit until the objective was taken

Name: Harold A. Garman
Notes: When a boat loaded with wounded came under fire from a German machine gun on the opposite river bank , he dove into the river braving enemy machine gun fire to tow the boat to safety

Name: Donald A. Gary
Place of action: Japanese home islands near Kobe , Japan
Notes: For braving hazardous conditions on the USS Franklin when it was hit by enemy fire to save sailors trapped inside the vessel 's hull

Name: Howard W. Gilmore †
Notes: While wounded on the bridge and unable to get below in time , gave the order for the submarine to crash dive to avoid an imminent attack , sacrificing himself to save the ship and the crew

Name: Harold Gonsalves †
Notes: While laying telephone lines for communication with the artillery battalion in Okinawa , he saved 2 other marines after flinging himself atop of a Japanese grenade and taking the full brunt of the resulting explosion allowing the other 2 men to complete the mission

Name: Donald J. Gott †
Notes: Piloted a B-17 aircraft on a bombing run on Saarbrücken . Even though his plane was severely damaged and set ablaze by anti-aircraft fire which wounded the engineer and the radio operator , Gott and co-pilot William E. Metzger , Jr. successfully dropped their bombs on the target and flew the plane to friendly territory . After having their crew bail out except for the unconscious radio operator , Gott and Metzger attempted to crashland the plane to save their helpless comrade . The plane exploded , killing the three remaining crewmembers on board

Name: William J. Grabiarz †
Notes: For using his body to shield a wounded officer from hostile fire

Name: Ross F. Gray †
Notes: Single-handedly overcame a strong enemy garrison and completely disarmed a large mine field before finally rejoining his unit

Name: Henry Gurke †
Notes: Fell on a grenade that landed in his foxhole , saving the man with him
